document.docTitle: The first record of the giant pill-millipede genus Prionobelum Verhoeff, 1924 from Thailand, with the integrative description of two species (Diplopoda, Sphaerotheriida, Zephroniidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The first record of the giant pill-millipede genus Prionobelum Verhoeff, 1924 from Thailand, with the integrative description of two species (Diplopoda, Sphaerotheriida, Zephroniidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig (ZFMK), Leibniz Institute for the study of biodiversity change (LIB), Section Myriapoda, Adenauerallee 127, D-53113 Bonn, Germany
Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig (ZFMK), Leibniz Institute for the study of biodiversity change (LIB), Section Myriapoda, Adenauerallee 127, D-53113 Bonn, Germany

subSection.paragraph: PATRICK DONWORTH 1,2 & THOMAS WESENER 1,3*

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig ( ZFMK ), Leibniz Institute for the study of biodiversity change (LIB), Section Myriapoda, Adenauerallee 127, D-53113 Bonn, Germany

subSection.paragraph:
2
ï¿½
s64pdonw@uni-bonn.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0009-0009-0047-1842

3
ï¿½
t.wesener@leibniz-lib.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-2028-3541

Thailand hosts a very rich but underexplored giant pill-millipede ( Sphaerotheriida ) fauna, with 11 of its 13 species described in the last three years. Currently, all known Thai giant pill-millipedes belong to the genera
Zephronia Gray, 1832
(nine species) and
Sphaerobelum Verhoeff, 1924
(four species). Here we describe the first two species of the genus
Prionobelum Verhoeff, 1924
(previously restricted to Vietnam and China ),
Prionobelum inthanonense
n. sp.
and
P. naevium
n. sp.
from Thailand . The species occur at Thailandâs highest mountain ( 2500 m ) Doi Inthanon and the lowland rainforests at Bang Lang National Park touching the border with Malaysia . Both species are described integratively, utilizing light microscopy, scanning electron microscopy as well as DNA barcoding. Both new species of
Prionobelum
differ from other Zephroniidae species, as well as from one another, by more than 20% p-distance in the COI barcoding gene suggesting that potential closer related species are still awaiting discovery.
Key words : DNA Barcoding , biodiversity , soil fauna

The giant pill millipedes (order Sphaerotheriida ) of Thailand are placed within the family Zephroniidae , the only family of the order found in Southeast Asia ( Wesener 2016a ). Thailandâs 13 species have heretofore been restricted to two genera:
Zephronia Gray, 1832
with nine species, eight of them described in the past three years (
Rosenmejer et al. 2021
;
Likhitrakarn et al. 2021
;
Srisonchai et al. 2021
; Bhansali and Wesener 2022 ) and
Sphaerobelum Verhoeff, 1924
with four species, three of them described in the past two years (
Wongthamwanich et al . 2012
; Bhansali and Wesener 2022 ;
Srisonchai et al . 2023
). This is still lower than the number of Zephroniidae species found in neighboring India , Vietnam and Laos ( Wesener 2016a ; Wesener 2019 ;
Semenyuk et al . 2018
, 2020 ). The pace of recent discoveries, however, suggests that the inventory in Thailand is far from complete.

In this contribution we provide the first record of the genus
Prionobelum Verhoeff, 1924
from Thailand . The genus was previously only known from Vietnam and, especially, China ( MauriÃ¨s 2001 ). We describe two species, one of which is found at over 2000 m above sea level on the northeastern Doi Inthanon, the highest point in Thailand , while the other is found near the Malaysian border in the low-lying Bang Lang National Park (
Misni et al . 2017
;
Sungkajanttranon et al . 2018
). We describe both species integratively, combining morphology with genetic barcodes. A molecular genetic barcoding study was undertaken to place these species in a tree relative to all Zephroniidae species for which COI sequences are presently available.
MHNG âMusÃ©um dâhistoire naturelle de la ville de GenÃ¨ve , Geneva , Switzerland
NHMD âNatural History Museum of Denmark , Copenhagen
SEM âscanning electron microscopy
ZFMK âZoological Research Museum A. Koenig, Leibniz Institute for Animal Biodiversity, Bonn, Germany ZMUCâZoological Museum, University of Copenhagen, Denmark

Scanning electron microscopy : For scanning electron microscopy ( SEM ), the endotergum and right antenna of each species were dissected. The samples were cleaned and dehydrated via an ethanol series (2x 96%, 3x 100%) before being mounted on aluminum stubs. The samples were coated with gold for 240 seconds in a sputter coater. SEM images were taken using a Supra VR 300VP (Carl Zeiss AG) scanning electron microscope utilizing the Software SmartSEM V05.00, based at the ZFMK .After the study, dry coated SEM material was removed from stubs and returned to alcohol. Images were subsequently edited in Adobe Photoshop 2023 and assembled into plates in Adobe Illustrator 2023.

Dissection, light microscopy, illustrations and habitus photographs : Dissection was done under a Zeiss Discovery V12. All terminology follows the recent literature ( Wesener 2016a ). Illustrations were produced by hand using paper and pencil with a camera lucida mounted on a Zeiss SteREO Discovery V12. Drawings were then inked to tracing paper with Pigma Micron pens sizes 04 and 005. Illustrations were scanned, touched up in Adobe Photoshop 2023 and assembled into plates in Adobe Illustrator 2023.

Habitus photographs were taken using a Nikon D750 with a Micro Nikkor 1:28 105 mm lens and Camera Control Pro 2 software. Photos were subsequently edited in Adobe Photoshop 2023 and assembled into plates in Adobe Illustrator 2023.

heading.emphasis: Tree description and genetic distances between species

subSection.paragraph: The gene tree might not be suitable to reconstruct deeper phylogenies, nevertheless the order Sphaerotheriida and the family Zephroniidae are recovered as monophyletic ( Fig. 1 ).

Our molecular analysis showed very low levels of intraspecific genetic distance for both species (see Supplemental material). The two specimens of
Prionobelum inthanonense
n. sp.
are separated by a p-distance of 1.8%, while the four specimens of
P . naevium
n. sp.
differ between 0â1.5%. The two new species differ from each other between 20.2â21.4%, with
P. naevium
showing the lowest distance to
Cryxus ovalis ( Linnaeus, 1758 )
(19.8%). Both species are placed in a group nested within the family Zephroniidae ( Fig. 1 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Maximum likelihood tree based on the COI sequence after 1000 bootstrap replicates analyzed with the General Time Reversible model. Numbers on branches indicate bootstrap support. Codon positions included were 1st+2nd+3rd. All positions with less than 95% site coverage were eliminated. The tree is drawn to scale, with branch length indicating genetic distance. Red and green box represent new species of
Zephronia
and
Sphaerobelum
respectively, yellow box species tentatively placed in
Sphaerobelum
, blue box
Prionobelum
,
Cryxus
and two unusual
Zephronia
.

subSection.paragraph:
Interspecific distances within Zephroniidae ranged from 11.7â30.4%, with the lowest observed between
Z. viridisoma Rosenmejer & Wesener, 2021
and
Z. panhai Srisonchai, Sutcharit & Likhitrakarn, 2021
. Both
Prionobelum species
described here are in the same clade, but not as sister-species ( Fig. 1 ).
P. inthanonense
n. sp.
is in the basal-most position. The species most closely related to
P. naevium
n. sp.
was found to be an unidentified Malaysian Zephroniidae from the Cameroon Highlands, roughly 180 km from the origin of
P. naevium
n. sp.
in Bang Lang, albeit with no statistical support ( Fig. 1 ).
P. naevium
n. sp.
and the Malaysian Zephroniidae are sister to a clade containing
Zephronia viridisoma Rosenmejer & Wesener, 2021
and a second unnamed species also placed in the genus
Zephronia
, both of which are found in Thailand .
Z. viridisoma
is found in Khao Lak, roughly 450 km from Bang Lang, and differs from
P. naevium
n. sp.
between 20.4â21.2%, while the latter
Zephronia species
is from the Aow Noi region, over 650 km from Bang Lang, and differs from
P. naevium
n. sp.
by 22.6â24.2%. These four species are sister to an unresolved node containing the likely
Prionobelum
from China , an undetermined female specimen placed tentatively in the genus
Sphaerobelum
from Laos (in Wesener 2019 ), as well as
Cryxus ovalis .
The seven aforementioned species constitute a clade to which
P. inthanonense
n. sp.
is the sister species ( Fig. 1 ).

heading.emphasis: Class Diplopoda de Blainville in Gervais, 1844

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks : See Wesener (2016a) for a catalogue of the family.

Type-species:
Chinosphaera maculosa Attems, 1935
.

Remarks : For a recent revision see the literature ( MauriÃ¨s 2001 ). The genus is still ill-defined, especially vis-Ã¡-vis the genera
Cryxus Leach, 1814
(see
Golovatch et al. 2012
) and
Tigridosphaera Jeekel, 2000
.

heading.emphasis:
Prionobelum inthanonense Donworth & Wesener
, new species

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 2A, B , 3â5
Material examined .

,
Thailand
, Chiang Mai Province , Doi Inthanon NP , main road,
2200 m
, coll. Zool. Museum Copenhagen ,
15.X.1981
;
1 male , 1 female , same data as previous, but
ZFMK MYR13661

.

Derivatio nominis .
inthanonense
, adjective, after the type locality.

Diagnosis .
Prionobelum inthanonense
n. sp.
is a medium-sized brown-chestnut colored species with a glabrous, shiny surface. The antenna is cylindrical, the legs with a short well-rounded coxal process ( Fig. 3A ), midbody legs with a single apical and 8 or 9 ventral spines.
P. inthanonense
n. sp.
differs from all other known
Prionobelum species
in the greatly enlarged vulva, with the operculum covering the whole of the prefemur and the mesal corner of the operculum further elevated ( Fig. 3C ). A membranous spot on the immovable finger of the posterior telopod ( Fig. 4A ) is otherwise only present in
P. hainani
and
P. joliveti ( MauriÃ¨s 2001 )
, but also occurs in some Thai species tentatively placed in the genera
Sphaerobelum
and
Zephronia
(
Rosenmejer et al. 2021
; Bhansali & Wesener 2022 ).
P. inthanonense
n. sp.
differs from all other known species of the genus in the anterior telopod having a strong hook with only three crenulated teeth ( Fig. 3DâF ).

Description (based on holotype )
.

Size : Length: 17.7 mm . Width of thoracic shield 8.5 mm , of widest segment (7th) 9.0 mm. Height of thoracic shield 5 mm , Height of highest segment (7th) 5.7 mm . Female: Length: 24.2 mm . Width of thoracic shield 11 mm , of widest segment (8th) 11.7 mm . Height of thoracic shield 6.1 mm , Height of highest segment (8th) 7.1 mm .
Head : Number of ommatidia 60. Organ of TÃ¶mÃ¶svÃ¡ry located within antennal groove.
Mandible : Not examined.
Gnathochilarium : Gnathochilarial palpi with sensory cones arranged in pads.
Collum : Mostly glabrous with two or three rows of sparse setae at the anterior margin.
Thoracic shield : Thoracic shield grooves wide and deep, with three sclerotized ledges along inner ridge ( Fig. 2A, B ).
Tergites : Paratergite tips on posterior half almost straight, very slightly projecting backwards. Tergites glabrous except for paratergite depressions. Shiny ( Fig. 2A, B ).
First stigmatic plate : With a well-rounded apex.

Legs : Ventral spines on leg 1: 2/3, on 2 4/?, on 3 5/6. Short apical spine present on leg 3. Single apical ( Fig. 3A , arrow) and 8 or 9 ventral spines on midbody legs. Femur not extended, lacking teeth, prefemur lacking processes. Femur 1.8, tarsus 4.1 times longer than wide. Coxae with conspicuous well-rounded mesal process ( Fig. 3A ).
Anal shield : Well-rounded and glabrous. Ventral side with single marginal locking carina, 5 times longer than those on tergites, located halfway between tergite margin and last pleurite.
Male sexual characters : Gonopore covered by simple apically membranous plate.

Posterior telopods ( Fig. 4A, B ): Inner horns elongated, protruding into a slender tip with a wide whitish membranous projection (not drawn). Podomere 1 wider than long, covered in setae anteriorly, and nearly glabrous posteriorly (4B). Podomere 2 with wide immovable finger, tapering only slightly near apex and bearing an ovoid membranous spot on posterior side ( Fig. 4A , arrow). Apex pointed and curved towards podomere 4. Immovable finger shorter than movable finger, only reaching apex of podomere 3. Membrane between immovable and movable finger with two strongly angled membranous lobes ( Fig. 4A, B ). Podomere 3 with sparse setation on anterior side, glabrous posteriorly. Podomere 3 ca. 3 times longer than wide, towards immovable finger with membranous ledge and one spine, posterior side with row of 10 black crenulated teeth ( Fig. 4A , arrow). Podomere 4 short, slightly curved, ca. 3 times longer than wide, with a short membranous ledge and 2 spines facing towards immovable finger ( Fig. 4B ).

Female sexual characters (based on paratype ; Fig. 3C ): Vulva large, covering 2/3 of coxa, with the massive operculum covering 1/2 of prefemur. Operculum larger than bursa. Operculum sparsely setose, apical margin extending into a small mesal lobe, which covers mesal prefemur. Subanal plate mesally invaginated, creating two distinct lobes separated by a suture, both lobes well-rounded.

FIGURE 5.

Abbreviations : Ad = apical disc; Ci = cuticular impression; Ma = middle area; Oa = outer area; sb = sensilla basiconica.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution . This species is apparently only occurring at the summit of Doi Inthanon above 2.000 m above sea level ( Fig. 6A ). There it appears to be common and regularly collected. A second unidentified Zephroniidae species (ZMUC K56x3B, K56x7B) was collected in sympatry with
P. inthanonense
n. sp.

heading.emphasis:
Prionobelum naevium Donworth & Wesener
, new species

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 2C , 6B , 7 , 8

Material examined .
Holotype :
Male ,
MHNG 4 B-1
, Thailand ( Province Yala ): Distr. Than To, Bang Lang National Park ( Than To Waterfall ),
150 m
,
1.II.1991
, leg. P. Schwendinger.

: 1 male ,
NHMD 1184671
, Thailand , Yala Province , Bang Lang NP , lowland rainforest, <
400 m
, 6Â°04âN , 101Â°11âE , coll. M. Andersen , O. Martin & N. Scharff ,
20.X.1991
;
1 female ,
NHMD 1184672
, Thailand , Yala Province , Bang Lang NP , lowland rainforest, <
400 m
, 6Â°04âN , 101Â°11âE , coll. M. Andersen , O. Martin & N. Scharff ,
20.X.1991
;
1 male ,
NHMD 1184673
, Thailand , Yala Province , Bang Lang NP , lowland rainforest,
270 m
, 6Â°11â47.5âN ; 101Â°9â50.9âE , coll. ATOL Expedition 2003,

.

Diagnosis .
Prionobelum naevium
n. sp.
is a large (> 35 mm length,> 20 mm width) giant pill-millipede species with a shiny, glabrous surface and a reddish-brown-black coloration pattern.
P. naevium
n. sp.
is far larger than all other known
Prionobelum species
, none of which are larger than 30 mm in body length. The axe-shaped antennomere 6 with>100 apical cones ( Fig. 8B ) is unique for this species among
Prionobelum
, with only
P. durum
showing a non-cylindrical antenna (which is swollen but not axe-shaped). The posterior telopod with telopoditomere 4 strongly projecting above the immovable finger ( Fig. 7E, F ) is shared with
P. durum
,
P. joliveti
,
P. leve
and
P. multidentata
, but
P. naevium
n. sp.
differs from all of the latter species in the shape and dentition of the anterior telopods ( Fig. 7BâD ).

Description (based on holotype )
.
Size : Length: 36.8 mm . Width of thoracic shield 21 mm , of widest segment (9th) 21.3 mm . Height of thoracic shield 11.4 mm , of highest segment (9th) 12.1 mm .
Head : Number of ommatidia ca. 70. TÃ¶mÃ¶svÃ¡ry organ located in antennal groove.
Gnathochilarium : Lamellae linguales with numerous long setae, medially glabrous. Sensory cones on gnathochilarium palps in pads.
Mandible : Not examined.
Collum : Largely glabrous with one row of setae on posterior margin and 2â3 rows near the anterior margin.
Thoracic shield : Thoracic shield grooves anteriorly narrow and steep, laterally wide ( Fig. 2C ), with 9 crests (sclerotized ledges?) on each side.
First stigmatic plate : rounded, with a sub-triangular apex.
Tergites : Tergites glabrous, shiny, at (100x magnification) sparse tiny pores become visible. Paratergite tips on posterior half straight ( Fig. 2C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. A. Map of Thailand with known distribution of
Prionobelum Verhoeff, 1924 species. B
. Habitus photograph of
P. naevium Donworth & Wesener
n. sp .
, from iNaturalist.org, CC, (c) Tanakorn.

subSubSection.paragraph: Pleurites : Pleurite 1 with a slightly elongated and very rounded tip. Pleurite 2 projecting less than 1 and with a very rounded apex. Pleurite 3 and following rectangular with no tip.

Legs : Ventral spines on leg pair 1 3/4, on 2 7/8, on 3 10/11. Apical spine on leg 3 present. A single apical spine and 12 to 14 ventral spines on midbody legs ( Fig. 7A , arrow). Femur regularly shaped, 1.9 times longer than wide. ( Fig. 7A ). Tarsus 4.5 times longer than wide ( Fig. 7A ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Prionobelum naevium Donworth & Wesener
n. sp.

Left posterior telopod, anterior view. F . Left posterior telopod, posterior view. Abbreviations : as = apical spine; cl = claw; ct = crenulated teeth; Cx = coxa; Fe = femur; imf = immovable finger; ml = two-tipped membranous lobe; Po = postfemur; Pre = prefemur; Sp-p = second podomere process; Syn = syncoxite = tarsus; Ti = tibia; vs = ventral spines. Scale bars = 1 mm.

FIGURE 8.
Prionobelum naevium Donworth & Wesener
n. sp.
holotype â ( MHNG 4B-1 ), SEM, A . Right antenna, basal 3 antennomeres, lateral view. B . Antennomeres 4â6 with disc. C . Detail of apical cone. D . Endotergum of midbody ring, overview; E . Endotergum, detail of marginal setae. Abbreviations : Ac = apical cone; Ad = apical disc; Ci = cuticular impression; Ma = middle area; Oa = outer area; sb = sensilla basiconica.

subSubSection.paragraph: Anal shield : Glabrous. One medium-sized locking carina 3 times the length of those on tergites, located close to margin.
Male sexual characteristics : Gonopore inconspicuous, consisting of large membranous opening located directly at mesal margin.

Distribution . Currently, this large and conspicuous species is only known from the lowland rainforests of the Bang Lang National Park where it appears to be relatively widespread ( Fig. 6A ). The smaller species
Sphaerobelum meridionalis Bhansali & Wesener, 2022
occurs in direct sympatry.

heading.emphasis: Intra- and interspecific distances of the COI gene

subSection.paragraph:
Our study, as well as previous ones, are greatly biased towards interspecific distances as they focus on the description of new species. Therefore, just a few sequences, always less than 10 and often from the same locality, allow intraspecific measurements. A further handicap to our barcoding study is the fact that no other sequences of the genus
Prionobelum
have been deposited in GenBank. The observed interspecific distances between the two new Thai
Prionobelum species
and the interspecific between the
Prionobelum species
towards related species are higher (minimum 19.8%) than those observed in giant pill-millipedes from Madagascar , where the species of
Sphaeromimus de Saussure & Zehntner, 1902
show interspecific distances of 8.3â20.8% (
Wesener et al . 2014
; Moritz & Wesener 2017 ), while the interspecific distances in the less well sampled genus
Zoosphaerium Pocock, 1895
are 9.1â20% ( Sagorny & Wesener 2017 ; Wesener & Anilkumar 2020 ). One reason behind the large interspecific distances of our two new species from Thailand could be that their closest relatives have not yet been discovered or sampled.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Our barcoding study highlights that the generic status of
Prionobelum
, especially vis-a-vis the Malaysian genus
Tigridosphaera
, the widespread genus
Sphaeropoeus
and the monotypic
Cryxus ,
is still ill-defined. However, we completely lack any molecular data of
Sphaeropoeus
and are limited to a single fragment of a mitochondrial gene in the other genera, making any phylogenetic conclusions impossible. Morphologically,
Prionobelum
is well-defined, based on the anterior telopod: in
Sphaeropoeus species
the process of podomere 2 forms a weak chela with a process on podomere 3, rather than with the apex (see Wesener 2016b ), while in
Prionobelum
the process and the apex (strongly bent backwards and sharp-edged) form a chela. Other character states have not been explored for the majority of
Prionobelum species
: they seem to lack additional apical spines on the walking legs, as well as the extended femur found in some (but by far not all!)
Zephronia
and
Sphaerobelum species.
Prionobelum species
seem to vary considerably in their antenna, antennomere 6 being either axe-shaped or (sub)cylindrical.
Prionobelum
shares with
Sphaerobelum
the often incompletely separated and sometimes completely fused podomeres 3 and 4 of the anterior telopod. A white membranous spot visible near the tip of the immovable finger of the posterior telopod is present in some species of
Prionobelum
(e.g.
P. hainani (Gressit, 1941)
and
P. inthanonense
n. sp.
), as it is in an unusual group of two
Sphaerobelum species
only tentatively placed in the latter genus (
Rosenmejer et al . 2021
; Bhansali & Wesener 2022 ). The apparently greatly enlarged operculum of the female vulva observable in some
Prionobelum species
( Fig. 3C ) seems to resemble such a structure observed in continental
Sphaeropoeus Brandt, 1833 species
(
Semenyuk et al . 2020
).
